baseline.ppi_scale: 1.0 = covers a daily family basket of essentials

civilizations.name: Babylonia (Old Babylonian)
civilizations.note: 1 shekel could buy ~300 liters of barley; enough for a family for weeks.

civilizations.name: Persian Achaemenid Empire
civilizations.note: Gold daric worth several days of food and clothing.

civilizations.name: Ancient Greece (Classical Athens)
civilizations.note: One drachma bought more grain than a family needed for a day

civilizations.name: Maurya Empire (India)
civilizations.note: One coin covered daily needs with modest surplus.

civilizations.name: Hellenistic Kingdoms
civilizations.note: A tetradrachm equaled four days wages, often used for bulk trade.

civilizations.name: Roman Republic & Early Empire
civilizations.note: 1 denerius covered daily food and some surplus.

civilizations.name: Han Dynasty (China)
civilizations.note: Wages covered subsistence food but limited surplus for other needs.

civilizations.name: Parthian / Sassanian Empire
civilizations.note: 1 Silver Drachm covered daily food and some surplus.

civilizations.name: Roman Empire (gold)
civilizations.note: High-value coin used for state payments, not daily life.

civilizations.name: Kushan Empire
civilizations.note: 1 Gold Dinar equal to 20 days of labour wages.

civilizations.name: Gupta Empire (India)
civilizations.note: 1 gold coin held large purchasing power, far above daily needs.

civilizations.name: Maya (Classic Period)
civilizations.note: 100 cacao beans covered food staples but little surplus for housing/clothing.

civilizations.name: Aztec Empire
civilizations.note: 100 cacao beans covered food staples but little surplus for housing/clothing.

civilizations.name: Inca Empire
civilizations.note: 1 day's labor tribute covered food, clothing, and some housing needs.
